cards.title: Game of Thrones / Hollywood would have ruined it, says books' author
cards.rawTitle: Hollywood would have ruined it, says books' author

item.title: George RR Martin: Hollywood would have ruined Game of Thrones
item.trailText: The fantasy author says film could not have coped with his Song of Ice and Fire doorstoppers: ‘The whole movie would be about this exiled princess’
item.standFirst: The fantasy author says film could not have coped with his Song of Ice and Fire doorstoppers: ‘The whole movie would be about this exiled princess’
item.body:
Some say cable TV long ago won its battle against film for longform storytelling supremacy – and that Game of Thrones, HBO’s dramatisation of George RR Martin’s A Song of Ice and Fire series of novels, was one of the fatal hammer blows. Yet, as the popularity and notoriety of Thrones on TV keeps on increasing, the question persists: why wasn’t it a series of movies?

Related: Trailer watch: Game of Thrones season five, episode 10 – Mother's Mercy

The answer, according to George RR Martin himself, is the one that anyone who’s lugged one of the books to and fro for several weeks on their commute might have in mind already. “It took Peter Jackson three movies to make Tolkien’s Lord of the Rings, and he still had to cut things,” Martin told The South Bank Show last night. “It would take three movies for A Storm of Swords alone!”

A Storm of Swords, published in 2000, was an 82-chapter, 992-page monster that took up all of season three of the TV show and most of season four.

“And if you figure two movies for A Game of Thrones, and two for A Clash of Kings,” Martin went on, referring to the first two doorstoppers in his series, slightly flimsier at 704 and 768 pages respectively, “you’re already up to seven movies and you’re halfway through. Nobody’s going to commit to that – and, of course, they didn’t commit to that.”

“The people I met from movies said one of two things. Some said, ‘Oh, we’ll just make the first movie! And after that’s a hit, we’ll make more.’ Well, of course, if you go down that route. then you have Philip Pullman’s His Dark Materials. Great fantasy, they made the first movie – didn’t do as well as they expected, and you’ll never see a second movie.”

Thrones relies on a combination of complex, gradually shifting power struggles and sudden, shocking developments. Both lend themselves to serialisation on television, where the set-ups can be detailed and the pay-offs can be doled out week by week, each of them becoming their own talking point rather than being bundled up into a film. But Martin said that, even in the best-case scenario, movies would mean not just losing the impact of most of his reveals, but losing some story points altogether.

Related: Game of Thrones recap: season five, episode nine – The Dance of Dragons

“Alternatively, they said, ‘Well, yes, it’s true it’s too complex; it’s too big the way it is – but we have to find the central arc. And we’ve decided the central arc should be Jon Snow.’ So the whole movie would be about Jon Snow.

“Or the central arc is Daenerys. The whole movie would be about this exiled princess, and she gives birth to dragons. That might be a good movie, and it might be interesting, but it wouldn’t be my story. My story is a combination of stuff.”

Martin therefore made the decision to take his books to HBO, which premiered the first season of Thrones in 2011. “I didn’t need the money, so I had the power to say the sexiest word in Hollywood – no.”

This does not mean, however, that there will never be a Thrones film. HBO’s president of programming, Michael Lombardo, isn’t keen: “When you start a series with our subscribers, the promise is that, for your HBO fee, we’re going to take you to the end of this,” he told Entertainment Weekly in March, adding that a movie would be “changing the rules. Now you have to pay $16 to see how your show ends.”

But George RR Martin has repeatedly dropped hints that, although it wasn’t right to begin the saga’s screen life in cinemas, ending it that way is his preferred option. “Sure, I love the idea,” he wrote on his blog earlier this year. “Why not? What fantasist would not love the idea of going out with an epic $100m feature film? And the recent success of the Imax experience [old episodes showing over Super Bowl weekend in January took $1.9m at the box office] shows that the audience is there for such a movie. If we build it, they will come.”

“But will we build it? I have no bloody idea.”

item.title: Miley Cyrus: 'I don’t relate to being boy or girl'
item.trailText: In a new interview, the Wrecking Ball star opens up about her sexual fluidity and says she told her mum she was bisexual at the age of 14
item.standFirst: In a new interview, the Wrecking Ball star opens up about her sexual fluidity and says she told her mum she was bisexual at the age of 14
item.body:
Miley Cyrus has revealed that she told her mum she was bisexual at the age of 14. The singer also claimed that her religious parents, who she describes at one point as “conservative ass motherfuckers”, found it difficult to accept at first.

“I remember telling her I admire women in a different way. And she asked me what that meant. And I said, I love them. I love them like I love boys,” Miley said to Paper Mag.

The Wrecking Ball star, who was breaking out as Disney star Hannah Montana at the time, added: “It was so hard for her to understand. She didn’t want me to be judged and she didn’t want me to go to hell. But she believes in me more than she believes in any god. I just asked for her to accept me. And she has.”

Back in May, Cyrus gave an interview to promote her Happy Hippie Foundation, which strives to help homeless and LGBT youth, in which she said that not all of her relationships had been “straight, heterosexual ones”.

But in this most recent interview, Cyrus explains that she is open to a variety of sexual relationships. She said: “I am literally open to every single thing that is consenting and doesn’t involve an animal and everyone is of age. Everything that’s legal, I’m down with. Yo, I’m down with any adult - anyone over the age of 18 who is down to love me. I don’t relate to being boy or girl, and I don’t have to have my partner relate to boy or girl.”

Cyrus adds that she’s had past relationships with women, but that they haven’t been brought into the media spotlight like her relationships with men.

Elsewhere in the interview, Cyrus says that she was inspired to set up a homeless charity after accepting the huge disparity between her life and the lives of others. She said: “I can’t drive by in my fucking Porsche and not fucking do something. I see it all day: people in their Bentleys and their Rolls and their Ubers, driving past these vets who have fought for our country, or these young women who have been raped. I was doing a show two nights ago, and I was wearing butterfly nipple pasties and butterfly wings. I’m standing there with my tits out, dressed like a butterfly. How the fuck is that fair? How am I so lucky?”

cards.title: 'Mittens of disapproval are on' / John Oliver mocks Jack Warner

item.title: British comedian John Oliver mocks Jack Warner on Trinidad television
item.trailText: John Oliver has paid for airtime on Trinidad television in order to ask the former Fifa vice president Jack Warner to reveal what he knows about corruption inside world football’s governing body
item.standFirst:
• Oliver pays for airtime with The Mittens of Disapproval Are On broadcast
• Warner had gone on same channel to insist he would expose corruption at Fifa
item.body:
The British comedian John Oliver has paid for airtime on Trinidad television in order to ask the former Fifa vice-president Jack Warner to stand by his word and reveal what he knows about corruption inside world football’s governing body.

In a four-minute segment shown on TV6, Trinidad’s largest private broadcaster, on Tuesday night, Oliver called on Warner to “release everything” after the disgraced 72-year-old and former president Concacaf president used his own paid-for political broadcast on TV6 to claim he had proof of Fifa wrongdoing.

Warner’s broadcast was called The Gloves Are Off, leading to Oliver, who has been a staunch and witty critic of Fifa for some time, largely in his role as presenter of the US show Last Week Tonight, to call his The Mittens of Disapproval Are On.

“I’ve been looking through the indictment,” said Oliver – who is originally from the West Midlands – during his message to Warner, “good luck with that”.

cards.title: Fifty Shades of Grey / Screenwriter says film is 'too painful' to watch
cards.rawTitle: Screenwriter says film is 'too painful' to watch

item.title: Fifty Shades of Grey screenwriter says film is 'too painful' to watch
item.trailText: Kelly Marcel reveals she was left heartbroken after EL James refused to allow any changes to her original dialogue
item.standFirst: Kelly Marcel reveals she was left heartbroken after EL James refused to allow any changes to her original dialogue
item.body:
Kelly Marcel, the screenwriter behind Fifty Shades of Grey, has revealed she has felt unable to watch the salacious blockbuster because the final cut was so different to her “crazy and artistic” original vision.

Related: Fifty Shades stars not bound to potential spin-off film

Production of Sam Taylor-Johnson’s film was plagued by reports that author EL James clashed heavily with the British director on set, with the novelist keen to ensure a more literal take on her bestselling book. Now Marcel has revealed she was left so disheartened by the experience of working on Fifty Shades of Grey that she has not been able to bring herself to see it.

“My heart really was broken by that process, I really mean it,” she told Bret Easton Ellis’s podcast. “I don’t say it out of any kind of bitterness or anger or anything like that. I just don’t feel like I can watch it without feeling some pain about how different it is to what I initially wrote.”

Marcel said her plans for a non-linear reading of James’ novel were initially received with enthusiasm by studio Universal. But she eventually came to realise that the British writer would only sanction a final cut that cleaved tightly to her own famously clunky dialogue.

“I didn’t want the story to be linear; I wanted it to begin at the end of the film, and for us to meet in the middle,” said Marcel. “So you start with the spanking, and you have these sort of flashes that go throughout the film … I wanted to take the inner goddess out, and all of Ana’s inner monologue … I wanted to remove a lot of the dialogue. I felt it could be a really sexy film if there wasn’t so much talking in it.

“When I delivered that script was when I realised that all of them saying, ‘Yeah, absolutely this is what we want!’, and, ‘You can write anything you like and get crazy and artistic with it’ – that was utter, utter bullshit. Rightly so. Erika was like, ‘This isn’t what I want it to be, and I don’t think this is the film the fans are looking for …’ Ultimately, Erika did have all of the control.”

__VIDEO_EMBED_gu-video-455416050__

Reports prior to Fifty Shades of Grey’s February release alleged that James threatened to withdraw her support for the film unless her original dialogue was retained. Studio Universal hired the award-winning playwright of Closer and Dealer’s Choice, Patrick Marber, to hone Marcel’s James-sanctioned screenplay. But the novelist reportedly went through the final script and removed all Marber’s tinkerings, threatening to alert her fans on social media if she were challenged.

Related: Fifty Shades of grating teeth: EL James 'threatened boycott' of film if dialogue rewritten

The author also reportedly refused to allow a subtle change to the film’s denouement in which Dakota Johnson’s Anastasia Steele was due to mutter the safe word “red” to Jamie Dornan’s kinky billionaire Christian Grey. In the final version, Taylor-Johnson and fellow film-makers were overruled, and Steele speaks the word used in the novel: “Stop.”

Taylor-Johnson admitted to fighting with James over the movie earlier this year, telling Porter magazine: “It was difficult, I’m not going to lie.” She has not signed on to direct follow-up Fifty Shades Darker.

Said Marcel: “There was a moment where we were weeks away from shooting … and it was clear that that was gonna be a struggle. It’s very difficult to come on as a director and to be handcuffed that way and not be able to fulfil your creative vision because there are certain restrictions on you. But at the same time, I would argue that it was very clear that that was the way it was going to be.”

Related: EL James's husband to write screenplay for Fifty Shades of Grey sequel

James is to take even tighter control over Fifty Shades Darker, which is expected to hit cinemas in 2017. The novelist has hired her husband Niall Leonard, who has previously written for TV shows including Ballykissangel, Wire in the Blood and Monarch of the Glen, to oversee the new screenplay.

Universal can reasonably argue that its approach has proven a highly profitable one. Despite scathing reviews, Fifty Shades of Grey scored $569.6m at the global box office and is likely to be one of the top 10 movies of 2015.

item.title: New Fifty Shades of Grey book stolen ahead of publication
item.trailText: A copy of Grey, the tale of Christian and Anastasia Steele told from the male perspective, has gone missing, with publishers fearing piracy and leaks
item.standFirst: A manuscript of Grey, EL James’s tale of Christian Grey and Anastasia Steele told from the male perspective, has gone missing, with publishers fearing piracy and leaks
item.body:
Fifty Shades of Grey author EL James’s forthcoming Grey, the story of the relationship between Christian Grey and Anastasia Steele told from his rather than her perspective – “Unlike any woman he has known before, shy, unworldly Ana seems to see right through him – past the business prodigy and the penthouse lifestyle to Christian’s cold, wounded heart” – is sitting pretty at the top of Amazon’s charts this morning, just over a week before its release.

But it turns out that one reader couldn’t wait until 18 June to get their hands on it: the Daily Mail reports that a manuscript was found to be missing yesterday, and “it is feared thieves may be planning to release pirated versions of the novel, or sell extracts to media outlets”.

Grey’s publisher Penguin Random House wouldn’t comment this morning “due to an ongoing police investigation”, but this is not the first time an early copy of a much-anticipated work has been swiped. In 2007, the final novel in JK Rowling’s Harry Potter series was leaked online days before its release, despite massive security. In 2003, a forklift truck driver stole pages of Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix, concealing them in his lunchbox, and attempted to sell them to the Sun.

The latest twist in the James saga is also eerily reminiscent of what happened to Stephenie Meyer, whose Twilight series was the original inspiration for Fifty Shades, back in 2008. Meyer was writing a fresh take on the story, from the perspective of the vampire Edward Cullen rather than the human teenager Bella, when a partial draft of Midnight Sun was stolen and made available online. The novelist, distressed by the leak, decided to stop writing the novel.

“I feel too sad about what has happened to continue working on Midnight Sun, and so it is on hold indefinitely,” she said at the time, making the first draft available online herself.

But the publisher assured fans this morning that Christian’s take on Ana’s “tangle of shapely limbs and tumbling brown hair” “will be published on June 18th - Christian Grey’s birthday - as planned”.

item.title: Orange Is the New Black: season three refresher course
item.trailText: Jenji Kohan’s prison drama returns for its third season on Friday but given it’s been 364 days since you binge-watched season two, you’ll need a cheat sheet to re-enter the world of Litchfield county jail
item.standFirst: Jenji Kohan’s prison drama returns for its third season on Friday but given it’s been 364 days since you binge-watched season two, you’ll need a cheat sheet to re-enter the world of Litchfield county jail
item.body:
Piper Chapman

When Orange Is the New Black began, Piper was our Wasp-y entry point into Litchfield penitentiary: a timid outsider struggling to learn the rules and rituals of a women’s prison. But, as the show’s cast has swelled, her significance has diminished. Her uncovering of institutional corruption in the prison was largely relegated to a B-plot last season, while the turf war between Red and Vee took prominence. Still, with Piper’s lover/antagonist Alex returning for season three – as a result of Piper having dobbed her in to her parole officer – you’d expect dandelion to have a bit more to do this time around. Thankfully, we’ll all be spared those long, dull conversations with her former fiance Larry (Jason Biggs) – he’s run off with her best friend Polly, and won’t return this season.

Friends: Alex (sometimes), Nikki, Red (sort of)

Enemies: Alex (sometimes), Pennsatucky

Likelihood of getting beaten up in the showers? High

Galina ‘Red’ Reznikov

Red used to be the top dog in Litchfield: the prison’s head chef, and the person who could get you just about anything, from tampons to Twinkies. But her kitchen duties were handed to her rival Gloria after she was caught facilitating rogue guard Pornstache’s drug trade. Then her attempts to continue the smuggling service in the prison’s greenhouse initiated a feud with long-time rival Vee, culminating in Red receiving an almighty lock-in-a-socking. Vee’s out of the picture now, having been run over by a prison truck driven by the absconding cancer patient Rosa in one of the show’s most satisfying scenes, meaning that Red has the all-clear to rebuild her empire, if she wants to. Will she make another play for the kitchen? Continue her illicit activities in the greenhouse? Or might she give up the game entirely and spent the rest of her sentence playing canasta with the Golden Girls? Matters are complicated somewhat by the fact that, back in the Bronx, the business she built with her husband has gone under without her knowing it.

Friends: The Golden Girls, Nicky

Enemies: Whoever gets in her way, Vee (if she’s not dead)

Likelihood of getting beaten up in the showers? Minimal. You don’t want to make an enemy of Red.

Dayanara ‘Daya’ Diaz

A storyline drawn from the most exaggerated of telenovelas: Daya is in love with and carrying the child of one prison officer, Bennett, having claimed that another officer, Pornstache, was the father. Pornstache was arrested for that infraction, and Bennett and Daya’s relationship still remains a secret, but one that will surely come out at some point. Daya, let’s remember, wants Bennett to come clean about the child’s parentage, even though that means Bennett will probably spend time in the clink as a result. Complicated.

Friends: The Hispanic bloc – Aleida, Gloria, Maria, Marisol – and Bennett, of course

Enemies: None really, now that Pornstache is out of the picture

Likelihood of getting beaten up in the showers? Slim to none

Poussey Washington

Another victim of Vee’s psychopathic tendencies, Poussey spent much of season two trying to convince the rest of her gang – Taystee, Black Cindy, Jeaney – that their new leader was up to no good, and ended up being beaten up and banished from the group for her troubles. With Vee gone she’s back in the fold, free to continue her bittersweet friendship with Taystee, whom she has the biggest of crushes on. Poor Poussey.

Friends: Taystee, Black Cindy, Jeaney

Enemies: Unrequited love

Likelihood of getting beaten up in the showers? In season two, high; now, not so much

Nicole ‘Nicky’ Nichols

After struggling with addiction and the death of her friend Tricia in the first season, Nicky’s was a more cheerful story arc in the show’s second run as she competed with Big Boo over who could get the most notches in their respective bedposts. Things can turn on a dime in OITNB though, and Nicky’s decision to hide the heroin she stole from Vee in an air vent looks likely to bring her face to face with her addiction again in season three. Storm clouds ahead.

Friends: Red, Piper, Morello, Big Boo

Enemies: Sweet lady skag

Likelihood of getting beaten up in the showers? Pretty high if Red gets wind of those drugs

Tiffany ‘Pennsatucky’ Doggett

A one-dimensional, white trash god-botherer with the worst teeth this side of Austin Powers, Pennsatucky was once OITNB’s most irritating character by a country mile. Yet, after receiving a monstrous beat-down from Piper, she received a pearly new set of gnashers and a new, softer demeanour in the show’s second season. She forged a sad, strange friendship with the flawed prison guard Healy in his Safe Space group, and – in one of the more unlikely developments in the show – became pally with Big Boo, and curious about the “counterculture”. As you do.

Friends: Big Boo, Healy

Enemies: Piper, her former acolytes

Likelihood of getting beaten up in the showers? High. Despite all of the above, she’s still pretty annoying.

Suzanne ‘Crazy Eyes’ Warren

Crazy Eyes was one of OITNB’s breakout characters in its first season, offering a depiction of mental illness that felt far more layered and optimistic than much of what we see on TV. Which made it all the more difficult to watch when her storyline turned decidedly dark last season. Suzanne fell under the spell of Vee, who convinced her to beat up Poussey and take the rap for the attack on Red. Only a late intervention by Healy saved her from a spell in max. Better things to come in season three, hopefully.

Friends: Taystee, Black Cindy, Jeaney

Enemies: None, though Poussey might find it hard to forgive her

Likelihood of getting beaten up in the showers? She’s more likely to do the beating.

Joe Caputo

Caputo is currently cock of the walk at Litchfield, having ousted the corrupt Figueroa as deputy warden. Caputo’s promising a kinder, more open penitentiary with him in charge, yet in what we’d seen of his brief tenure at the end of season two, he’d already been forced to hush up the revelation that Bennett is the father of Daya’s child. He’d do well to remember Figueroa’s parting words: “Good luck with your noble intentions, this place will beat them out of you.”

Friends: The members of his band, Sideboob

Enemies: Anyone who’s had the misfortune of witnessing his band Sideboob live

Likelihood of getting beaten up in the showers? Highly unlikely, bar an unforeseen prison riot

Sophia Burset

Arguably the best trans character on TV, Sophia rises above all of Litchfield’s petty infighting, preferring to dispense life lessons and affordable haircuts at her salon. Instead, the source of her drama comes from her relationship with her son Michael, who is beginning to accept her after years of resistance. Expect that relationship to be explored in this third season, along with the usual array of devastating one-liners.

Friends: Everyone

Enemies: No one

Likelihood of getting beaten up in the showers? Don’t even try it.

cards.title: Ticking the boxes / Can an online quiz spot a psychopath?
cards.rawTitle: Can an online quiz spot a psychopath?

item.title: Can an online quiz spot a psychopath?
item.trailText: Online quizzes claim to unmask the psychopaths among us. But just how accurate are these tests?
item.standFirst: Online quizzes claim to unmask the psychopaths among us. But just how accurate are these tests?
item.body:
People are fascinated by the nature of the psychopathic personality. Lurid tales of con men and serial killers capture our imagination and feature prominently in films like No Country For Old Men and Silence of the Lambs. Recent popular books on the topic like The Psychopath Test and The Wisdom of Psychopaths have brought psychopathy into the public consciousness, claiming to unmask the psychopaths among us or show how psychopathic traits can be advantageous.

Psychopathy is a rare and serious personality disorder, which is primarily diagnosed in criminal justice settings. Individuals with psychopathy lack empathy and remorse, do not emotionally connect with other people, are manipulative, use other people to their own ends and are often aggressive or violent. Psychopaths are estimated to make up approximately 1% of the population, but comprise up to 20% of the prison population.

So could you or someone you know be a psychopath? Lately there has been a proliferation of online tests that claim to settle this question once and for all. Some of these appear to be endorsed by people with academic credentials and in many instances it is unclear whether these people have actually led any empirical research on psychopathy. Although some people probably take these quizzes just for laughs, others may well be seeking genuine feedback about their personality. However, it is unlikely that any of these tests are able to reliably identify psychopaths. To get a diagnosis of psychopathy, an individual has to score a minimum of 30/40 on a standard diagnostic instrument that relies on recorded, independently verified information from institutional files, as well as an in-depth interview administered by a trained professional. General members of the public would typically struggle to score more than 4/40 on this instrument and would lack the institutional file information necessary to complete the diagnostic protocol.

Nevertheless, the characteristics of psychopathy fall along a continuum. People may endorse that they have some psychopathic traits without actually having a full-blown psychopathic personality disorder. But scoring relatively high on some of the features of psychopathy does not make a person a psychopath. Consequently, there is a concern that psychopathy quizzes may suggest to people with psychopathic traits that they in fact are bona fide psychopaths. To explore this possibility, we used our knowledge of psychopathic traits to see what these quizzes would make of people with such traits. The results were worrying. Some of these quizzes included a disclaimer at the start noting that “these are not diagnostic tests”, but the feedback we received suggested otherwise. OK Cupid’s quiz, for example, informed us:

Wow, you are a genuine psychopath. You lack empathy, are highly manipulative, disregard the law, and don’t even have any delusions to blame for your behaviour. Therapy is unlikely to help you and would in fact just make you better at manipulating others. Chances are that most people don’t even realize just how sick you are.

This quiz claims to be a “real test used to diagnose criminally insane psychopaths”. Our diagnosis:

Well... Looks like you’re a Psychopath! But hey, that’s not always a bad thing. You guys get a bad image, people always think you kill people. That’s totally not true! With your manipulative attitude you could be anything you want, why limit yourself to murdering people?

As scientists working in this field, this type of feedback is deeply worrying to us. We are concerned about trivializing a serious personality disorder and its appropriate measurement, which is not helpful to those who have the disorder or to their unfortunate victims.

The second issue is that self-rating instruments are never perfect and there is a great deal of room for error – particularly when the instruments have not been subjected to rigorous empirical study assessing their reliability, validity and ability to capture individual differences in the population. We see no evidence that the online quizzes have undergone these procedures and as such what constitutes a high score is likely to just represent someone’s subjective opinion. It is also unclear how reliable people’s self-assessments of some features of psychopathy are, which is precisely why in criminal justice settings the diagnosis relies on file information and comparing interview findings with the file information. A person may feel less empathy and be more manipulative than the average Joe, but this is not necessarily abnormal - it is more than likely just normal variation in personality.

In light of this, it is worrying that no support or adequate debriefing is provided for individuals who take these quizzes. Instead many of the sites were very happy to declare someone a psychopath and leave it at that. Such feedback is undoubtedly distressing for some people. In particular, those who encounter these quizzes on dating websites might be especially concerned about how such feedback reflects on their social abilities. At worst, the feedback was irresponsibly congratulatory and even appeared to exhort people to capitalize on their “psychopathic personality” to use others for personal gain. We were also concerned about some of the feedback “diagnosing” the respondent as a psychopath and telling them that they cannot change and that no therapy will work for them. Such feedback is misinformed. There is evidence that therapy can help psychopaths, particularly in youth.

Finally, misdiagnosing someone with some psychopathic traits as a full-blown psychopath could license antisocial behavior by suggesting to that person they are not responsible for their behavior. For example, studies have shown that people are more likely to cheat after reading an article suggesting that free will is an illusion.

In sum, the use of online quizzes to “diagnose” psychopathy is dodgy science at best and ethically irresponsible at worst. These quizzes are not valid tools for measuring a serious personality disorder that causes a great deal of suffering for many people. Properly diagnosing psychopathy requires assessment by trained professionals and convergent evidence from a variety of information sources. Online quizzes might be fun, but they are probably better suited for assessing your knowledge of pop music than for self-diagnosing a serious personality disorder.

item.title: Dr Feelgood’s Wilko Johnson on Shunkoin Temple in Kyoto
item.trailText: The rock band’s founder and guitarist found perfect tranquility in a Japanese monastery after being diagnosed with terminal cancer
item.standFirst: The rock band’s founder and guitarist found perfect tranquility in a Japanese monastery after being diagnosed with terminal cancer
item.body:
I love Japan. I’ve been there many times, working and just being there, over the last 30 years. When I was diagnosed with terminal cancer at the beginning of 2013, the first thing I wanted to do was go to Japan, particularly Kyoto. If you want a bit of tranquility, they’ve got plenty of it. One particular highlight I remember was in a monastery called Shunkoin up in the hills. There was nobody there except a monk sweeping up the leaves – it was such a tranquil setting.

Shunkoin Temple was established by Horio Yoshiharu in 1590 to honour his son, Horio Kinsuke, who died in the Battle of Odawara, and to worship his ancestors. The temple is surrounded by gardens – the Garden of Boulders, the Garden of Tokiwa, the Crane and Turtle Garden, and many shrines too. It is lovely just to walk around and soak in the ambience and stillness of it all. You can stay overnight at the temple guest house, called the Cave of Enlightened Dragon – the names are amazing.

Related: The best restaurants in Tokyo and Kyoto – chosen by Japan’s top chefs

I was standing on a balcony looking out over the roofs to a valley where huge pine trees were growing. It was snowing and the sun was shining through the snow and made it golden. I was just standing there, looking at this golden snow coming gently down, and thinking my life is going to come to an end. Normally if you’re confronted by a sight like that you would try and impress it on your memory so that you can refer to it in future times. But I was thinking, “I don’t have any future times, I’ve just got this.” I thought, I’ve just got to live in this moment now – and it gave me an absolutely perfect moment.

• wilkojohnson.com, shunkoin.com
